occurrences.line_text: And long time with that saluage people staid,
And gently askt, where all the people bee,
His chosen people purg'd from sinfull guilt,
Then all the people, as in solemne feast,
And all the way the ioyous people sings,
Whom all the people decke with girlands greene,
A route of people there assembled were,
That to their people wealth they forth do well,
Gathered the Princes of the people loose,
Was by the people chosen in their sted,
Of these a mightie people shortly grew,
At sight whereof the people stand aghast:
That thy sad people vtterly fordonne,
Of dying people, during eight yeares space,
And mighty people, dreaded more then all
And hellish arts from people she might hide,
To saue his people sad from victours vengefull hands.
And all the people in that ample hous
With which he pinched people to the hart,
What time his people into partes did riue,
To barre the prease of people farre away;
Of people, thronging thicke her to behold,
Admir'd of all the people, and much glorifide.
That did resort of sinfull people shonne;
And warlike people, which the Britaine Islands hold.
And wonned there, where now Yorke people dwell;
Sad Trowis/, that once his people ouerran,
And to all people did diuide her dred beheasts.
And rule his people right, as he doth recommend.
Doest to thy people righteous doome aread,
Full many people gathered in a crew:
That when the people, which had there about
Whom when as all the people such did vew,
Forth from the thickest preasse of people came,
True Iustice vnto people to diuide,
A rout of many people farre away;
Eftsoones the people all to harnesse ran,
Causd all her people to surcease from fight,
Rather then see her people spoiled quight,
Which he vnto her people does each day,
And making all her Knights and people to doe so.
All full of people making troublous din,
And hearing pleas of people meane and base.
But thine owne people do thy mercy prayse much more.
Robbed her people, that full rich had beene,
And all the people both of towne and land,
My children and my people, burnt in flame;
That all the people there without it heard,
Then all the people, which beheld that day,
A rout of people they before them kend,
His scattred people, ere they all were slaine,
Which when the people round about him saw,
And all her people murdred with outragious might.
The people of the house rose forth in great vprore.
Who hearing how his people badly sped,
A lawlesse people, Brigants hight of yore,
And all his people captiue led away;
Appeard for people in nor out to pas,
That all the people where so he did go,
No other noyse, nor peoples troublous cryes,
Farre from all peoples prease, as in exile,
In which the tract of peoples footing was,
All bare through peoples feet, which thither traueiled.
And peoples harts with awfull terrour tye,
For Cadwan pittying his peoples ill,
Both for his griefe, and for her peoples sake,
But wholy wast, and void of peoples trode,
That it prodigious seemes in common peoples sight.
Vnto his caue farre from all peoples hearing,
From peoples knowledge labour'd to concele.
The spoile of peoples euill gotten good,
How he mis-led the simple peoples traine,
Couered from peoples gazement with a vele.
The peoples great compassion vnto her allure.
Then gan the Peoples cry and Commons sute,
Before his feete, in all that peoples sight;
That taketh vengeaunce of his peoples spoile.
And shrieke aloud, that with the peoples voyce
He chaunst to come, far from all peoples troad,
Pinckt vpon gold, and paled part per part,
Does seeke to perce: repining courage yields
And eke enchaunted armes, that none can perce,
Perce to my hart, and pas through euery side,
That nought mote perce, ne might his corse be harmd
His harder hide would neither perce, nor bight,
Not perceable with power of any starre:
By the great persue, which she there perceau'd,
Faire Damzell, that with ruth (as I perceaue)
Was throughly heal'd. Tho when they did perceaue
Whom when so willing Artegall perceaued;
Eftsoones he perced through his chaufed chest
The point of pitty perced through her tender hart.
Which when the valiant Elfe perceiu'd, he lept
Whose corage when the feend perceiu'd to shrinke,
Perceiu'd my thought, and drownd in sleepie night,
Which when the wakeful Elfe perceiu'd, streight way
Whom when his maistresse proud perceiu'd to fall,
Which when the vile Enchaunteresse perceiu'd,
But for in court gay portaunce he perceiu'd,
At last when as the Sarazin perceiu'd,
Which whenas she perceiu'd, she was dismayd
There well perceiu'd he, that it was the horse,
Perceiu'd to be such as they seemd in vew,
Perceiu'd would breede great mischiefe, he bethought
Out of the field, that none perceiu'd it plaine.
They which remaynd, so soone as they perceiu'd,
Which when their Host perceiu'd, right discontent
Which when as he perceiu'd, he thus bespake;
Nigh as he drew, they might perceiue his head
Yet each doth in him selfe it well perceiue to bee.
To whom approching, well he mote perceiue
Anon she gan perceiue the house to quake,
To hide her wound, that none might it perceiue:
Well did the Squire perceiue him selfe too weake,
Whose hidden drift he could not well perceiue;
They might perceiue, she was not well in plight;
He mote perceiue a litle dawning sight
He mote perceiue by signes, which he did fynd,
She mote perceiue a litle purple mold,
Perceiued him to wauer weake and fraile,
Whom when as he perceiued to respire,
And well perceiued his deceiptfull sleight,
Lucinaes aide: which when they both perceiued,
But when her well auizing, he perceiued
Who well perceiued all, and all indewed.
Which when as fearefull Amoret perceiued,
Whence being forth produc'd, when she perceiued
Which troublous stirre when Artegall perceiued,
Which when the cruell Amazon perceiued,
Which when as Zele perceiued to abate,
Which vncouth vse when as the Prince perceiued,
Yet this in all her words might be perceiued,
To whom approching, when as she perceiued
Which he perceiuing greatly gan reioice,
Which he perceiuing, euer priuily
And then perceiuing, that it was indeed
Which Triamond perceiuing, weened sure
Which Scudamour perceiuing, forth issewed
But Artegall by signes perceiuing plaine,
Perceiuing well the treason, which was ment:
Who well perceiuing, how her wand she shooke,
Which Artegall perceiuing, strooke no more,
Whom Calidore perceiuing fast to flie,
Which she perceiuing, did with plenteous teares
By which she well perceiuing, what was done,
Who it perceiuing, hand vpon him layd,
Whom them perceiuing, streight to him obayd,
Which Calidore perceiuing, thought it best
That point of speare it neuer percen could,
Perceth the yielding ayre, and doth displace
To seeke, if he perchance a sleepe were layd,
But with that percing noise flew open quite, or brast.
Such percing griefe her stubborne hart did wound,
Which when that Champion heard, with percing point
The percing steele there wrought a wound full wyde,
With piteous mone his percing speach gan paint;
With percing shriekes, and many a dolefull lay;
And saw it stirre: she left her percing launce,
With percing words, and pittifull implore,
That through his threesquare scuchin percing quite,
As percing leuin, which the inner part
Percing his hart with pities point did thrill;
Beare off their blowes, from percing thorough quite.
Of whom a knight, no knight at all perdee,
That Redcrosse knight, perdie, I neuer slew,
Perdie Sir knight, said then th'enchaunter bliue,
Perdie (said Trompart) let her passe at will,
Ah Dame, perdie ye haue not doen me right,
Perdie, then is it fit for me (said he)
Ne had they footing found at last perdie,
Perdie (said Britomart) the choise is hard:
For perdie one shall other slay, or daunt:
For perdie else how mote it euer bee,
Perdie great blame, (then said Sir Calidore)
Perdie (said he) in euill houre it fell,
And all that might him to perdition draw;
Perdy (said he) here comes, and is hard by
Perdy (quoth he) yet neuer eye did vew,
Yet wist, she was not well at ease perdy,
Perdy me leuer were to weeten that,
Perdy, (said Satyrane) thou Squire of Dames,
He sigh'd, he sobd, he swownd, he perdy dyde,
Perdy nay (said Malbecco) shall ye not:
Perdy not so; (said she) for shamefull thing
Perdy thou peasant Knight, mightst rightly reed
But wise and warie was that noble Pere,
Then said that royall Pere in sober wise;
To haue a pere in part of soueraintie,
Whose soueraine beautie hath no liuing pere,
Nor Prince, nor pere it is, whose loue hath gryde
To proue some deedes of armes vpon an equall pere.
That bold he said; ï¿½ most redoubted Pere,
To a great pere; but she did disaccord,
Was greatly growne in loue of that braue pere,
Yet was she lou'd of many a worthy pere;
They were two knights of perelesse puissance,
With peremptorie powre, that made all mute;
That challenge did too peremptory seeme,
Of sage and sober Peres, all grauely gownd;
Emongst thine equall peres, where happie blis
Of those same antique Peres, the heauens brood,
Amongst his peres playing his childish sport:
To hunt the saluage chace amongst my peres,
That all her peres cannot with her compare,
And bring into a mighty Peres displeasure,
But all of Diamond perfect pure and cleene
Shortly therein so perfect he became,
Eft soones of him had perfect cognizance,
For when they once to perfect strength do grow,
Th'other immortall, perfect, masculine,
There sate a man of ripe and perfect age,
And form'd so liuely in each perfect part
Hauing their wearie limbes to perfect plight
It vertue had, to shew in perfect sight,
Vnto these Sprights, to bring to perfect end.
To whom in perfect loue, and spotlesse fame,
So all did make in her a perfect complement.
To be vpbrought in perfect Maydenhed,
In which when she to perfect ripenesse grew,
So sure and swiftly, through his perfect scent,
And mingled them with perfect vermily,
So perfect in that art was Paridell,
With perfect peace, and bandes of fresh accord,
Faire Dame he might behold in perfect kind;
And perfect hole, prostrate she fell vnto the ground.
In perfect loue, deuoide of hatefull strife,
Which being once withdrawne, most perfect hew
That was a Ruby of right perfect hew,
No lesse then perfect gold surmounts the meanest brasse.
For of most perfect metall it was made,
So feeble skill of perfect things the vulgar has.
Known by good markes, and perfect good espiall,
Till he to perfect ripenesse grew, and then
Most perfect pure, and guiltlesse innocent
So milde humanity, and perfect gentle mynd.
For he through long and perfect industry,
Of perfect loue did sow, that last forth brought
And prou'd the perfect pleasures, which doe grow
In perfect forme, as this good Lady felt,
Which to another place I leaue to be perfected.
To such perfection of all heauenly grace,
And rare perfection in mortalitie,
Till to her dew perfection she was ripened.
And heauenly image of perfection,
Adorn'd with all diuine perfection,
For till the world from his perfection fell
And her perfections with his error taint:
So great perfections did in her compile,
For th'one of them he perfectly descride,
And perfectly practiz'd in womans craft,
Thus when the Prince had perfectly compylde
And perfectly well shapt in euery lim,
Which see not perfet things but in a glas:
Yet thus perforce he bids me do, or die.
To meete me wandring, who perforce me led
Yet liue perforce in balefull darkenesse bound?
That to the ground he is perforce constraynd
Perforce rebutted backe. The weapon bright
Patience perforce; helpelesse what may it boot
He made him stoup perforce vnto his knee,
Yet him perforce restraynd, and to him doubtfull sayd.
Which chaunge of colour did perforce vnfold,
Perforce their studies broke, and them besought
And them perforce withheld with threatned blade,
Hereto perforce. But ï¿½ dred Soueraine
Perforce disparted their compacted gyre,
But him perforce vnto the ground it bore:
And that perforce, for want of lenger light,
His wearisome pursuit perforce he stayd,
Perforce her carried, where euer he thought best.
His force, at last perforce a downe did ly,
Yet he perforce him held, and strokes vpon him hept.
But patience perforce he must abie,
And all perforce to make her him to loue.
That seeke perforce her from you both to take,
Till fortune did perforce it so decree.
But haue perforce him hether brought away.
To see the sight perforce, that both her eyes were loth.
Then gan he thinke, perforce with sword and targe
And now perforce they haue him prisoner taken;
And with their ryder ranne perforce away:
But th'vtmost end perforce for to aby,
Performd, in paragone of proudest men:
And well perform'd, as shall appeare by his euent.
Which when he had perform'd, then backe againe
Vnlesse it be perform'd with dreadlesse might.
Thy weaker Nouice to performe thy will,
Which for my part I couet to performe,
Which she would sure performe, betide her wele or wo.
And promist to performe his precept well,
It to performe: so after little stay,
At last he was compeld to cry perforse,
Vpon his shoulders carried him perforse
Out of his wauering seat him pluckt perforse,
Perforse him pluckt, vnable to withstand,
Loth was the Dwarfe, yet did he stay perforse,
And Guyon would him algates haue perforse,
All which when Talus throughly had perfourmed,
They all perfumde with frankincense diuine,
Warnd him not touch, for yet perhaps remaynd
Least thou perhaps hereafter wish, and be withstood.
Perhaps my succour, or aduizement meete
(Said he) perhaps ye should it better find:
On one, that worthy may perhaps appeare;
May her perhaps containe, that else would algates fleet.
Perhaps this hand may helpe to ease your woe,
That ill perhaps mote fall to either side.
Perhaps I may all further quarrell end,
Abett, perhaps he mote it deare aby.
That may perhaps you better much withall,
But Peridure and Vigent him disthronized.
Or thou, Sir Peridure, her sorie state,
And perill without show: therefore your stroke
Yea but (quoth she) the perill of this place
Then of the certaine perill he stood in,
Ne yet of present perill be affraid;
There dwell in perill of like painefull plight,
At perill past, and yet in doubt ne dares
His wandring perill closely did lament,
What hath poore Virgin for such perill past,
And will be found with perill and with paine;
Atchieuement wrought with perill and with paine,
Then thought the Prince all perill sure was past,
Ne ought saue perill, still as he did pas:
His toward perill and vntoward blame,
With some late perill, which he hardly past,
Long after she from perill was releast:
She went in perill, of each noyse affeard,
From perill free he her away did beare:
And mickle perill to be put to shame.
For shew of perill, without venturing:
That hauing once escaped perill neare,
And I without your perill or your cost,
How to preuent the perill that mote rise,
Though for her sake they all that perill tooke,
Carelesse of perill in their fiers affret,
Ne either car'd to ward, or perill shonne,
So worthie of the perill, worthy of the paine.
Ne any dar'd their perill to partake;
Who whatsoeuer perill was prepared,
Both equall paines and equall perill shared:
Whom without perill he cannot inuade.
I her preseru'd from perill and from feare,
Withouten dread of perill to repaire
Withouten perill of the stronger pride:
Her person late in perill, did remaine,
And to the place of perill shortly came.
As if some proued perill he did feare,
And faint-heart-fooles, whom shew of perill hard
Thus hauing past all perill, I was come
Till I was throughly past the perill of his reach.
For feare of perill, which to him mote fall,
Into redoubted perill forth did call;
So ought each Knight, that vse of perill has,
In which all stroue with perill to winne fame.
Against them durst his head to perill shew.
Whom on his perill he did vndertake,
Vnknowen perill of bold womens pride.
But the bold child that perill well espying,
Yet still he striues, ne any perill spares,
So when that Knight from perill cleare was freed,
All perill ought be lesse, and lesse all paine
A storme approching, that doth perill threat,
But I that knew my selfe from perill free,
Into this bay of perill and disgrace?
Of perill, or of ought that might befall:
And saw his carriage past that perill well,
The perill of his pride, or else be ouerrun.
Both for the perill of the present stound,
And perill by this saluage man pretended;
Vpon him set, of perill nought adrad,
Her selfe now past the perill of her feares.
Great perill of his life, and restlesse paines did take.
Which oft through pride do their owne perill weaue,
Ne any paines ne perill did he shonne,
To leaue his Loue, now perill being past,
Vnweeting of the perillous wandring wayes,
All change is perillous, and all chaunce vnsound.
Those two false brethren, on that perillous Bridge,
Till to the perillous Bridge she came, and there
So to pursue a perillous emprize,
To visite, after this nights perillous passe,
Through that same perillous foord with better heede,
And past through many perillous assayes,
And proued oft in many perillous fight,
And thousand perills which them still awate,
She fownd not in that perilous house of Pryde,
And stray in perilous gulfe, her dwelling is:
And glorious spoiles, purchast in perilous fight:
My litle boat can safely passe this perilous bourne.
As Pilot well expert in perilous waue,
And counseld him abstaine from perilous fight:
Now when report of that their perilous paine,
Now comes to point of that same perilous sted,
On th'other side, they saw that perilous Rocke,
On th'other side they see that perilous Poole,
After long wayes and perilous paines endured,
That none durst passen through that perilous glade.
And brought through points of many perilous swords:
In perilous fight, she neuer ioyed day,
A perilous fight when he with force her brought
The perilous present stownd, in which their liues were set.
That seemd some perilous tumult to desine,
With many wounds full perilous and wyde,
That he remayned in most perilous plight,
He gan bethinke him, in what perilous plight
At last when perils all I weened past,
The house of Pride, and perils round about;
Ay me, how many perils doe enfold
And to the place, where all our perils dwell;
Of straunge aduentures, and of perils sad,
Out of my way, through perils straunge and hard;
passing through perils great,
The sacred soile, where all our perils grow;
Where daungers dwelt, and perils most did wonne,
To hunt out perils and aduentures hard,
And many perils past in forreine lands,
Approued oft in perils manifold,
And rash prouoking perils all about,
Deserued for their perils recompense.
And of the perils whereto he was bound,
That pittie is to heare the perils, which she tride.
Through many perils wonne, and many fortunes waide.
For that faire Ladies loue: past perils well apay.
In greater perils to be stout and bold,
Who now to perils great for iustice sake proceedes.
The greater prowesse greater perils find.
To perils great; which he vnbuckling eft,
Through many perils and much way did pas,
In perils strange, in labours long and wide;
That you into such perils presently doth call?
Was much emmoued at his perils vew,
And past through many perils by the way,
Full many pathes and perils he hath past,
O helpe Orgoglio, helpe, or else we perish all.
Ne suffred them to perish through long eld,
But young Perissa was of other mind,
The recompence of their periured oth,
Thou falsed hast thy faith with periurie,
And guiltie heauens of his bold periury,
Of perle and precious stone, that earthly tong
And twixt the perles and rubins softly brake
That like pure Orient perles adowne it trild,
For gold, or perles, or pretious stones an howre,
Gold, amber, yuorie, perles, owches, rings,
Few perling drops from her faire lampes of light;
To ferry that old man ouer the perlous foord.
In PhÃ¦drias flit barke ouer that perlous shard.
Vntill he quite had spent his perlous store,
For here before a perlous passage lyes,
As lay her iourney, through that perlous Pace,
Ne durst assay to wade the perlous seas,
Thence forth descending to that perlous Porch,
Approued oft in many a perlous fight.
Whilest I through paines and perlous ieopardie,
With perly deaw, and th'Earthes gloomy shade
They also doe by his diuine permission
Would not permit, to make their lenger stay,
By meanes whereof she would not him permit
Ought thy remembraunce, and perpetuall band
A friendly league of loue perpetuall
And by succession made perpetuall,
Some of deare louers, foes perpetuall:
Wroth with the Gods, which to perpetuall paine
Could iudge what paines do louing harts perplexe.
Could find no rest in such perplexed plight,
That when he heard, in great perplexitie,
Yet is she now in more perplexitie,
In pensiue plight, and sad perplexitie,
The secret cause of his perplexitie:
She found her selfe assayld with great perplexitie.
And soone him ouertooke in sad perplexitie.
In heauy plight and sad perplexitie;
Him Talus tooke out of perplexitie,
On th'other side, in huge perplexity,
In such distresse and sad perplexity
Of flaming, and her selfe in great perplexity.
But this same both her selfe, and others eke perplext.
Yet wondrous quick and persant was his spright,
So passing persant, and so wondrous bright,
And through the persant aire shoote forth their azure streames.
That as a swords point through his hart did perse,
That horror gan the virgins hart to perse,
Yet I perseuer'd still to knocke and call,
Though much emmou'd, but stedfast still perseuered.
Ne Persia selfe, the nourse of pompous pride
And like a Persian mitre on her hed
As the proud Persian Queenes accustomed:
The wealth of th'East, and pompe of Persian kings;
After the Persian Monarks antique guize,
But now seemde best, the person to put on
Did yield her comely person, to be at my call.
Of her chast person, and a faithfull mate
Was like the person selfe, whom he did beare:
Her single person to their barbarous truth,
And made her person thrall vnto his beastly kind.
A goodly person, and could menage faire
Ne yet her person such, as it was seene,
Adornes the person of her Maiestie;
Eftsoones supposed him a person meet,
